journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: A new model-free adaptive controller versus non-linear H∞ controller for levitation of an electromagnetic system

contrib-group.aff: Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Islamic Azad University, Urmia Branch, Urmia, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Ali Javadi, No. 1.1, Esfand Lane, Salmas Street, Urmia 5717663445, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: alijavadi88@ms.tabrizu.ac.ir

abstract.p: In this paper we aim to survey the performance of a non-linear H∞ method and a new proposed controller on a magnetic levitation model (maglev). The proposed controller is a new model-free adaptive design approach using an adaptive-fuzzy procedure based on feedback linearization. The main idea of the new controller comprises two steps: first, by means of the feedback linearization method, a measured signal is taken to a specific level with an error less than a defined value and second, proposed rules are applied to the system to keep the error near zero. The major advantage of new controller is that there is no need for identification of the system dynamics and only the output error is required.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to various advantages of magnetic levitation (maglev) trains including high speed, low energy consumption, no direct environmental pollution, high capacity and high safety and reliability, recently there has been a great tendency to set up the required substructure to use maglev as innovative transportation in many countries. Maglev technologies can be categorized in two types: electrodynamic suspension (EDS) and electromagnetic suspension (EMS). In EDS technology, a repulsive magnetic force is used to levitate the train on the track, which has inherently stable levitation dynamics and there is no need to control the distance between the train and the guideway. Indeed, because of the unstable nature of levitation dynamics in EMS technology, there is a strong need to control the distance between the train and the track. For this purpose, many controllers have been presented in the benchmark such as PID (Liu et al., 2009), linear H∞ (Bittar and Sales, 1997), quantitative feedback theory (QFT) (Nataraj and Patil, 2008), sliding mode (Al-Muthairi and Zribi, 2004) and adaptive control (Sinha and Pechev, 1999). Because of uncertainties in the maglev system, robust adaptive controllers such as the methods introduced in Mahmoud (1996), Xu and Feng (2007) and Ge et al. (2005) can be used; however, in this paper, we will apply model-free adaptive (MFA) and non-linear H∞ control methods to stabilize an EMS train to a specific distance.

Model-free adaptive control (MFAC), as its name implies, is an adaptive control method without setting up the model of process. It uses I/O data of the controlled system to design the controller without knowing any information of the system. Han and Wang (1994) started primary research on a model-free control topic. They proved the stability of MFAC, and Hou (1994) expressed the theory and applications of model-free control in his PhD thesis. the idea of this model introduces a new pseudo-gradient vector and uses the I/O data to estimate the pseudo-gradient vector of the process for the MFAC.

Vandegrift et al. (1995) have designed a fuzzy logic controller for a limited class of non-linear systems of the form x(k + 1)=f(x(k)) + u(k) + w(k), where f(x) is an unknown non-linear function and Lyapunov stability analysis was presented for this restricted class of systems. Jagannathan (1996) extended the design and stability analysis of an adaptive fuzzy logic controller to feedback linearizable non-linear systems of the form x(k + 1)=f(x(k)) + g(x(k)) + u(k) + w(k).

Another idea was proposed by Cheng (2000), in which a neural network is used as an adaptive controller to stabilize the plant. It has been demonstrated that this algorithm can be applied to any multi-input system that is stable controllable without complicated manual tuning for controller parameters.
Some advantages of the MFAC framework are:

list-item.p: no precise quantitative knowledge of the process is available;
no process identification mechanism or identifier is included in the system;
no controller design for a specific process is needed.

sec.p: The rest of the paper is organized as follows: next, the non-linear dynamics of the magnetic levitation system is described. Then the design procedure of non-linear H∞ and adaptive fuzzy methods are represented. The new controller is proposed, followed by simulation results, given to highlight the advantages of the MFA method. Finally, the conclusion is given.

sec.title: Maglev non-linear model
sec.p: A schematic of a single-degree-of-freedom EMS system with a controlled dc electromagnet is shown in Figure 1 (Sinha and Pechev, 2004).

caption.p: Magnet guideway configuration of the system used in this paper. Guideway disturbance is introduced by the oscillating mechanism on the top left corner.

sec.p: The dynamic model of this system has been described in Sinha (1987):

sec.title: Non-linear H∞ controller
sec.p: By defining a state vector x=[z(t) z·(t)i(t)]T and external disturbance vector w=[(t) w2(t)]T and rewriting (1), a non-linear state space model of open loop system is obtained as follows:
α1 and α2 are gains of the two disturbance inputs. The following penalty vector has been supposed to manipulate states and control effort.
where β1, β2, β3 and wu are design parameters, which can be used to change the transient response of the states and control effort. Taking bigger weight (wu) limits the u to be lower and vice versa.

The objective of the non-linear design procedure is to identify a class of controllers that keep the energy of the penalty vector less than the energy of disturbance input by satisfaction of the L2-gain inequality as described in Van der Schaft (1992)

Using the concept of dissipativity and storage function developed in Willems (1972), if there is a non-negative smooth storage function V(x(t)) that satisfies the following Hamilton–Jacobi–Isaac (HJI) inequality, the stability of equilibrium point is assured (Isidori and Kang, 1995)

Any feedback law that satisfies the above HJI can make a closed-loop system locally dissipative and stable. With D=D12TD12 and C1TD12=0 for a maglev model in a saddle point, the worst case input disturbance and minimizing value of the control effort are given by:
By rewriting inequality (5) using (6a), the following HJI inequality is obtained:

The above HJI inequality rarely can be solved analytically. As a result, an approximation should be exploited. Here an infinite sum inequality by a Taylor series is utilized with the kth power term as
where A[1]x, A(x)[2], …A(x)[k] are the first, second, …kth terms in the Taylor series expansion of A(x) in (2a). Similarly, by expanding w⌢ and u⌣ by a Taylor series, we have:
where B1[j], B2[j] and Vx(x)[j+1], j=1, … , k, are the Taylor series expansion of B1(x), B2(x) and the storage function V(x), respectively.

list-item.p: The first-order controller, u⌣[1], and worst case disturbance vector can be obtained by replacing k=1 in (8) as
With k=1, (7) has the following form:
The second-order controller is u⌣[1] + u⌣[2], where u⌣[2] is given with k=2 in (8)

sec.p: and the corresponding HJI inequality is given by substituting k=2 in (7)
The Taylor expansion of Equations (2) in the nominal operating point z0=13 mm, i0=3.1395 and u0=3.4535 with N=280, m=1.5, am=0.01024 m2, Rm=1.1 Ω and defining h=µ0N2am are as follows
To derive a first-order controller, we assume a quadratic storage function (Lyapunov function) V(x)[2]=xTPx with P>0, and the HJI inequality can be rewritten as the following Riccati equation

In Ball et al. (1993), the stability of the linearized system with a quadratic Lyapunov function is demonstrated. If a non-negative quadratic Lyapunov function can be found such that (9b) is satisfied or equivalently the Riccati equation (12) is solvable, then the first-order controller ensures the local stability of the system around the nominal point. Assuming α1=α2=1, β1=β2=β3=1, wu=0.1 and γ=1, a solution of the Riccati equation using Matlab software gives
With this P, the first-order controller and worst case disturbance are given by:

It has been proven that if a linearized system has a suboptimal solution corresponding to γ, as is the case here, there exists a unique solution for higher order non-linear H∞ controllers (Abu-Khalaf et al., 2006).
To obtain a second-order controller, V(x)[3] is defined as the cubic polynomial
and substituted into (10c). By simplifying (10c) and setting coefficients of the terms with equal powers to zero, {ci}, i=1 … 10 are derived as
Using the above coefficients and substituting V(x)[3] into (10a), the second-order controller is given by

It should be noted that u0 is added to both first- and second-order controllers to levitate the mass at the nominal distance (z0) and the other terms related to u⌣[1] and u⌣[2] are responsible for damping the negative effects of disturbance, noise and uncertainties.

sec.title: Adaptive fuzzy controller using feedback linearization
sec.p: In the feedback linearization method, control law is determined in such a way to eliminate the non-linear terms of the system dynamics and replace it with the appropriate reference input as seen below:

Conceptually, adaptive feedback linearization (AFL) method is the same as its non-adaptive counterpart but AFL uses an adaptation law or updating equation to update the controller parameter to enhance its performance. Notice that both methods should have a complete description of the system dynamics to design the controller; thus in this paper we will try to find a way that does not need any information about the system dynamics. Because it is difficult to obtain a mathematical model of the system and typically there exist some numerical approximations, the object of this paper is controlling systems just with I/O data in order to control the output of system adequately. To reach this goal it is required that we estimate the unknown non-linear function of system dynamics f(x) and g(x) with f^(x) and g^(x) or estimating the control law u(t) with u^(t)(t). The exploited estimation algorithm in this approach utilizes the basic fuzzy membership function. As an instance, for estimating f(x), we have the following:

where p is number of fuzzy roles for system, μi(x) is membership function for the ith fuzzy role and state x, and ci is result of ith fuzzy role for that system, which are generally considered a linear combination of some series of continuous functions such as z(x).
Using (18), can be rewritten as:
where E(x) is an approximation error of fuzzy approach. A(t) is updated by the below adaptation law:
Q is a constant coefficient that is usually opted to be small. By the above equation, es is difference between output x and the reference output xref:
It should be pointed out that the adaptive fuzzy controller (AFC) guarantees that A(t) approaches its desired value, A*(t).

Notice that initial values of A(t) can be opted randomly, e.g. A(0)=0, or be selected by information that is acquired from the system dynamics, or even be determined from another available control approach; for instance, columns of A(0) can be taken as kf (kf is obtained from the state feedback method u=−kfx), or for example if we want to estimate the f(x) function, columns of A(0) are better containing coefficients of the system states of f(x) (Ordonez et al., 1997). Fuzzy rules are expressed as follows:
If X is Fi then ci=fi(z)
fi(z) is related to the ith row of the zTA matrix. So the unknown non-linear function f(x) is estimated as f^(x) by the fuzzy approach.

sec.title: Proposed approach
sec.p: Consider an input affine system with a general form of:

At first, to control the system, non-linear functions f and g must be estimated in such a way that they do not rely on system dynamics. The proposed method in this paper is a combination of the fuzzy estimator and initiative law. The estimations of the system dynamics are defined as:
and updating values of u^g, u^f are given by:

where αf, αg are constant coefficients with respect to u^f,u^g. It should be noted that usually these parameters do not need to be changed for different system dynamics. The value of I is defined in Equation (34) and also in Equations (25) and (26), r(t) is the so-called ‘filtered tracking error’, which is the sum of the errors as defined below:

where {λi}, i=1 …n are error derivative coefficients in the next level or, in other words, coefficients of predictive error and Δt is a step size of simulation. According to above equation, yd is the desired output and errors are the difference between the desired value and the actual output of system obtained at different times. To eliminate non-linear terms of system dynamics, the feedback linearization method has been exploited; for this purpose, u(t) is chosen as follows:
where v(t) is a new input and defined as:

In Equation (30), kv is the tracking error coefficient and is called the ‘gain matrix’. By choosing the appropriate kv, r(t) converges to zero and finally causes v(t) to be restricted. In other words, if we opt for a bigger kv, better performance of the output and a quick tendency to the desired value is achieved while the control signal u increases; it should be noted that if kv is chosen to be very large, it can make the system unstable.

As seen from Equation (29), the problem of singularity occurs when g~ is near zero and the control signal can become unbounded. To solve this problem, a separate controller comprising two parts is proposed in the following form:

In the above equation, s is a constant value, the value of which impacts on control signal u. Also σ is a constant parameter for determining the upper bound for the produced control signal uc by the AFC approach. If it is selected as small (meaning 1/σ becomes large), this makes the system unstable, and uc and ur are defined as:

where δ is robust control signal coefficient so that its decrement or increment affects the quantity of the final control signal u and g¯ is a constant value so that its small amount decreases the effect of ur on the final control signal u, i.e. ur will become a more effective factor for determining u; and I is given by the equation below:

Here g¯ is the lower bound for g~ so that choosing an appropriate value for it prevents function g~ being singular and s is another designing parameter that causes the controller just to use the final control signals (u).

Remark 1.
σ , δ
and s are designing parameters with the following conditions (Jagannathan, 1996):
Remark 2. If uc is greater than 1/σ, it is assumed equal 1/σ.
The major principles of the proposed MFA controller are constructed based on the following three experimental rules, which make the controller produce an appropriate control signal:

where ε is the threshold value for changing the final control signal u in the above rules. These laws utilize an appropriate last level control signal (if the error becomes less than the specified value that is called ε) for use at the next level. Indeed if the error at time t and t−Δt becomes less than ε and the error at time t is greater than the previous time, the controller applies a reverse value of the previous control signal for the current time.

Note that the adaptive fuzzy controller estimates unknown non-linear functions of system by a fuzzy algorithm and each time a new reference input is applied to the system, this estimation becomes better, but the sensitivity of the proposed controller on estimation of non-linear functions is lower than the AFC method. This is because the output error has a significant role in the control effort, rather than a significant role in the estimation in AFC.
For the maglev dynamics depicted in Figure 1, MFA parameters have been selected as follows:

, u^g(0) are the initial estimation values of uf, ug. It should be noted that the output of system is sensitive to these initial values and should be carefully selected.

sec.title: Simulation results
sec.p: To evaluate the performance of non-linear H∞ controllers and the proposed MFA controller, several scenarios have been considered. In the following subsections, the effect of input disturbance and measurement noise will be investigated on the performance of all controllers.

sec.title: Without disturbance and measurement noise
sec.p: It is supposed that the initial distance is 10 mm and the reference input changes from 10 to 16 mm. In this section, the input disturbance and measurement noise is considered zero. In Figure 2, the distance and control efforts using both controllers have been shown.

caption.p: (a) and (b) Simulation results for a Maglev train without disturbance and measurement noise with reference input of 10–16 mm; (c) and (d) are the corresponding control signals.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 2, there is no steady-state error in the tracking input reference signal. The MFA controller has a low amplitude oscillation around 16 mm, which occurs due to discontinuous nature of Equation (35). Besides, non-linear H∞ controllers stabilize the distance in a less time than the MFA controller, and have smooth results.

sec.title: With input disturbance and without measurement noise
sec.p: In this subsection, measurement noise is considered zero but a 20% input disturbance (fd=0.2 mg) has been applied at t=1.5 s. The numerical results are shown in Figure 3. Because of the approximation used in solving HJI, there is a steady-state error for non-linear H∞ controllers. As is expected and is clear in Figure 3, a second-order non-linear H∞ controller gives less errors than the first-order non-linear H∞ controller.

caption.p: (a) and (b) Simulation results for a Maglev train with disturbance and without measurement noise with reference input of 10–16 mm; (c) and (d) are the corresponding control signals.

sec.p: As is obvious from Figure 3(a) and (b), the steady-state error for the MFA controller is approximately zero – for first-order controller 2.15 mm and for the second-order controller 1.9 mm. Evidently, in the presence of an input disturbance, the new MFA approach outperforms the non-linear H∞ method because the MFA controller keeps the error less than a specified value regardless of what the reference value is.

sec.title: With disturbance and white Gaussian measurement noise
sec.p: In this subsection, we apply both white Gaussian measurement noise (originating from the distance measurement sensors) and a 20% input disturbance to the system. The distance and control signals are shown in Figure 4. The power of the applied Gaussian noise is 8×10−8. This amount of noise power has been chosen to be small because nominal values of the distance are in the millimetre range.

caption.p: (a) and (b) Simulation results for a Maglev train with disturbance and white Gaussian measurement noise with reference input of 10–16 mm; (c) and (d) are the corresponding control signals.

sec.p: Considering Figure 4(b), it is seen that input disturbance produces only a steady-state error using the non-linear H∞ controller, whereas noises cause the output to oscillate around nominal point. Considering Figure 4(a), the MFA controller has a very low sensitivity to the external disturbance but exposes a small steady-state error against the measurement noise. By comparing Figures 4(a) and (b), MFA clearly has a smoother output than the non-linear H∞ output, which indicates a significant advantage over the proposed controller.

sec.title: With disturbance and sinusoidal measurement noise
sec.p: Like the previous section, an input disturbance exists here, but instead of white Gaussian noise, a sinusoidal signal is applied. This sinusoidal noise can be interpreted as oscillations produced by an earthquake, which affects the track. Both controllers perform better against sinusoidal noise with higher frequencies, but before the threshold frequency for each of the controllers, noise is amplified. The non-linear H∞ controller starts to attenuate measurement noise at f=7 Hz and the MFA starts attenuating in f=1 Hz. When the frequency of the noise is 15 Hz, as illustrated in Figure 5, non-linear H∞ controllers successfully lower the effect of the measurement signal by a factor of 70% at the output, whereas the MFA controller reduces the noise by only 30%.

caption.p: (a) and (b) Simulation results for a Maglev train with disturbance and sinusoidal measurement noise with reference input of 10–16 mm; (c) and (d) are the corresponding control signals.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: MFAC is an adaptive controller that just uses measured states of the system and does not require other system states. Although the MFA controller is fairly vulnerable against measurement noise but has some merits such as good stability, appropriate tracking, robustness against uncertainty and disturbance rejection, the biggest advantage of MFA controller is not requiring system dynamics. Despite the fact that the non-linear H∞ is a robust method, which performs well against disturbance and uncertainties, the simulation results indicate that the proposed MFA method is more effective in disturbance attenuation and parametric uncertainties. Of course, some time specifications such as settling time and overshoot for non-linear H∞ outperform the MFA controller.

app.title: Notation
app.p: m Mass of the levitated object
N Number of turns in the magnet winding
z Distance between mass and track
u Input voltage of the coil
x State vector of the maglev model
βi Designing parameters of non-linear H∞ method
wu Weight parameter of control effort in non-linear H∞ method
ci Consequent of ith fuzzy rule
Q Constant coefficient in adaption law
σ Upper bound of control signal uc
δ Robust control signal coefficient in MFA method
s, g¯ Designing parameter in MFA method
η Constant coefficient in proposed rule

f
(0) Initial estimation values of uf

(0) Initial estimation values of ug
